notesStmt.note: Any special notes on this text? (optional)

sourceDesc.p: Information on named entities in this file has been extracted from files in the Digital Mitford Archive.

person.note: Poet laureate of the UK from 1850 to 1892, following Wordsworth. Buried in Westminster Abbey.

death.placeName: Northampton General Lunatic Asylum, Northampton, Northamptonshire, England

person.note: Called the peasant poet, Clare worked as an agricultural laborer and manservant.
Mentioned in Francis Needham’s biographical listings of people in Mitford’s circles or relevant to her work. More research needed.
In Mitford's time, a captain retired from the Royal West regiment of the London militia. Later became a magistrate and served as mayor of Reading.
Spouse of Jacob Newbery. Name variously spelled Newbery and Newberry.
Solicitor at 35 Great Queen's Street, Lincoln Inn Fields, London; and at Friar Street, Reading. Spouse of Mrs. Newbery. Name variously spelled Newbery and Newberry.

Mitford's letters in December 1820 indicate that Henry Marsh was involved in a local political tiff with Henry Hart Milman. The rift between Henry Marsh and H.H. Milman is well documented. See The History of Parliament online.

item.name: wisteria
Wisteria
Fabaceae
item.note: Woody climbing bine bearing cascading purple flower plumes, native to Asia and to the eastern US.

item.name: azalea
Rhododendron
Ericaceae
item.note: Flowering shrub carrying abundantly showy red, pink, or white blooms in spring, related to rhododendrons. Grow in the understory of woodlands, and have been hybridized as garden shrubs for hundreds of years. Native to Eurasia and North America. Introduced to the UK in the 19th century as a garden ornamental, it is now considered an invasive species.

item.name: rhododendron
Rhododendron ponticum
Rhododendron
Ericaceae
item.note: Flowering shrub carrying abundantly showy round flower clusters in shades of mauve or lavendar blooms in spring, related to rhododendrons. Grow in the understory of woodlands, and have been hybridized as garden shrubs for hudreds of years. Native to Eurasia and North America. Introduced to the UK in the 18th century as a garden ornamental, it is now considered an invasive species.

item.name: cottongrass
Eriophorum angustifolium
Eriophorum
Cyperaceae
item.note: Sedge that develops fluffy white heads.

item.name: heart's-ease
Viola tricolor
Viola
Violaceae
item.note: Wild pansy native to the UK

item.name: common snowdrop
Galanthus nivalis
Galanthus
Amaryllidaceae
item.note: Small white-flowered plant propagated by bulbs, native to Europe and the Middle East and widely naturalized elsewhere. Believed to be native to the UK since the 16th century. Flowers in late winter and early spring, around the vernal equinox and so is considered a harbinger of spring. May also symbolize purity, hope, or the Christian Holy Trinity. A frequent subject of 19th century poetry including works by Landon Wordsworth, and others.

item.name: hepatica
Anemone hepatica
Anemone
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Low-growing flowering plant with fleshy, trilobal leaves and blue, purple, or pink flowers with showy white stamens. Flowers in late winter and early spring. Native to Europe and Asian and naturalized as well as grown as a garden plant in the UK.

item.name: winter aconite
Eranthis hyemalis
Eranthis
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Yellow flowering plant native to Europe and naturalized in the UK. One of the earliest woodland wildflowers, appearing in late winter. Unrelated to aconitum (monkshood).

item.name: fuchsia
fuchsia magellanica
fuchsia
Onagraceae
item.note: Small upright or spreading flowering shrub, with showy, pendulous bi-colored blooms in combinations of red, pink, purple, and white sepals and petals. A large genus, native to the Carribbean islands, Mexico, central and South America. Now a widely grown garden shrub and pot plant. F. coccinea and F. magellanica, both from South America, were being cultivated in England by the late eighteenth century. Vineyard Gardens in Hammersmith, England introduced fuchsias to the gardening public, as well as introducing and popularizing imports such as the China rose and dahlia as garden plants.

item.name: garden mignonette
Reseda odorata
Reseda
Resedaceae
item.note: Tall, thin pale yellow flower spike growing from base leaves. Native to Europe, the Mediterranean region, and southwest Asia. In the 19th century, grown in gardens and windowboxes for its fragrance. Also used in perfumery, potpourri, and as a cut flower in arrangements. R. luteola, another species, was a source of yellow dye.

item.name: hop-bines
Humulus lupulus
Humulus
Cannabaceae
item.note: Twining plant using stiff, hairy stems (bines) to climb. Flowers of the female plants are the source of hops, used in brewing to flavor beer

item.name: common wallflower
Erysimum cheiri
Erysimum
Brassicaceae
item.note: Flowering plant native to the Mediterranean basin and widely used as a garden plant for its showy, fragrant clusters of racemes in yellow-orange.

item.name: common myrtle
Myrtus communis
Myrtus
Myrtaceae
item.note: Evergreen flowering shrub bearing white flowers with many showy white stamens and dark blue edible berries. Native to the Mediterranean region and Western Asia to India. Associated with Jewish, Greek, and Roman ritual and myth, symbolizing honor, prosperity, hope, and love. In early-modern Europe, the floweres became traditional in bride's bouquets because of their associations with love and happiness.

item.name: common buttercup
Ranunculus acris
Ranunculus
Ranunculaceae
item.note: A small yellow flowering plant first catogorized by Carolus Linnaeus in his 1753 Species Plantarum. It is a herbaceous perennial plant that grows to a height of 30 - 70 cm, with ungrooved flowing stems bearing glossy yellow flowers about 25 mm across. There are five overlapping petals borne above five green sepals that soon turn yellow as the flower matures. It has numerous stamens inserted below the ovary. The leaves are compound, with three lobed leaflets. In horticulture the species may be regarded as a troublesome weed, colonising lawns and paths. However, it may be a welcome feature of wildflower meadows. The double-flowered cultivar R. acris 'Flore Pleno' has gained the Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit.

item.name: ranunculus
Ranunculus asiaticus
Ranunculus
Ranunculaceae
item.note: A species of buttercup (Ranunculus) native to the eastern Mediterranean region in southwestern Asia, southeastern Europe (Crete, Karpathos and Rhodes), and northeastern Africa. Double-flowered forms, which are likely hybrids, are a popular ornamental plant in gardens, and widely used in floristry.

item.name: potato
Solanum
Solanum tuberosum
Solanaceae
item.note: Potatoes are relatively new to Europe at this time. They are native to the Andes and were introduced only in the second half of the 16th century by the Spanish.

item.name: tuberose
Polianthes xxx
Polianthes
Asparagaceae
item.note: A perennial plant that is frequently used in perfumes.
